commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Noted chairman?  (5)
2. Whom you might meet with open arms, for short?  (3)
3. What a comment might be made in  (4)
4. Spirals out of control?  (9)
5. Fights back tears?  (5}


EAMES
TSA
JEST
TORNADOES
DARNS
This was FUN ‚ÄòN GAMES.
This one had some bite to it for a Monday.  Liked it.
Trip to Hong Kong allowed me to know nihao, but there was some crunch. Figured out the theme early on and made for a great solve

After I got started, I thought this might be a good puzzle to see how far I could get with only across clues. I actually got pretty far‚ÄîI had to check a down in ROCKNROLL to see what went in the AND space (thought it might be an ampersand, although that would be pretty odd for a Monday); I didn‚Äôt know the filmmaker and misspelled NIHAO; had YIELD before ALERT; and was looking for some tubular pasta instead of RAVIOLI and couldn‚Äôt come up with the rather generic POPSONG. But that was it. It was an interesting exercise but a shame really because most of the more interesting entries were down, including the revealer, which I discovered when I scanned the puzzle at the end. Pretty Light n‚Äô Easy.

Not only was there a lot of ROCK N ROLL in this fine Monday puzzle, I was reminded of one of one of my favorite groups with the tune Head OVER Heels. My friend from high school has been their drummer for the past 15 years or so. Love me some Tears for Fears üòç https://youtu.be/CsHiG-43Fzg?si=CA1YdAB_gVLebxGK Enjoy and happy Monday!
This puzzle was FAST N EASY.
I love a quick and fun puzzle on a Monday. Caught on easily, which isn‚Äôt always true. Thanks, Adam! Y‚Äôall have a great day!

This was fun to the Nth degree.

Thanks, Adam.

Good easy Monday puzzle.  A bit funny to see TERSER as an answer after that was the last word I got on Friday.

Also not the first time the last word I got right was ELON, referring to the college and not the billionaire.  I first put down OASIS not realizing it pluralized to OASES, and it was my one square 'Amiss'.
Fun fairly easy but entertaining. Thank you Adam!
I liked this a lot. The 'ad free' was a great way to glue it all together, very impressive to deliver all those '___ n ___' fills + a fun thematic reveal , all within a bright, sunny Monday puzzle
It‚Äôs 2025: can we stop with the racist clues about Inuit‚Äôs homes (IGLOO). Inuits are normal people who live in houses. The tropes are exhausting.

Hiccuped on the trick and did not break my record by thirty seconds.  Drats. 

Did find fall colors, peace, and quiet.  My inner librarian has been read.
It somehow only took me a minute more to solve the full puzzle than the mini today. I got really skunked on the Mini

Enjoyed solving this Light N Lively Monday puzzle from Adam.

Some may recall Light N' Lively cottage cheese, which weirdly has only the one apostrophe in the name after the N. IMO truly one of the most awful things I've ever tasted, and it had a weird sheen to it.
It's always bugged me that Rock and Roll is often stylized as "Rock N' Roll" -- with one apostrophe, not two. And that's how Guns N' Roses spells their name too.

HAYAO?
NIHAO?
OHNO!

"Promise you'll take me to the ice cream parlor?"
"Sure, let's shake on it."

(They'll wear their sundae best.)

Clever construction, with a little challenge or two. Fortunately, the crosses came through and completed the blank spots.

Nice one, Adam, and thanks!

Disclaimer: I‚Äôm crabby from a long weekend and a prolonged disdain from the state of the world, but this was tough for a Monday. Some obscure proper nouns, a few naticks (for me) and a revealer clue found late in the down clues, which if it came earlier or in the crosses could have kept me from second guessing English as my first language. 

No hate to the constructor, I‚Äôm just grumpy and this particular Monday puzzle didn‚Äôt help set my week off in a good mood. Thanks for entertaining my gripe, fellow NYC crossword solvers!

What a nifty Monday puzzle. ROCK N‚Äô ROLL indeed. 

A fun fact: The reduction of ‚Äòand‚Äô to ‚Äòn‚Äô  English is about 800 years old, both in pronunciation and writing. Prior to that, the ‚Äòd‚Äô in Old English ‚Äòand‚Äô (also found as ond, endi, or und) was always voiced. We know this from OE manuscripts, where it was never shortened to ‚Äòn‚Äô or ‚Äòa/en‚Äô but rather written out (unless replaced by the Tironian et (‚Åä) symbol, the precursor of our ampersand (&)), as well as from how OE poetry reads, where the ‚Äòd‚Äô in ‚Äòand‚Äô has to be fully voiced with an alveolar stop or it breaks meter. 

(Additional fun fact, that voiced ‚Äòd‚Äô is about 3 millennia old, with proto-Germanic andi/unda dating back to the Bronze Age.)

But then comes Middle English, and ca. the 13th c. scribes start writing ‚Äòand‚Äô as ‚ÄònÃÑ‚Äô or ‚ÄòenÃÑ.‚Äô (I‚Äôm using apostrophes here to denote italics. The apostrophe as a typographical way of denoting elision in speech only enters English in the 16th c. as printers adopt the Greek ·ºÄœÄœåœÉœÑœÅŒøœÜŒøœÇ or apostrophos or turning away. Before that, a macron over the ‚Äòn‚Äô indicated elision.) So we now see phrases such as ‚Äòale n wyn‚Äô or the medieval version of SURF N‚ÄôTURF, ‚Äòfysshe n fleissh.‚Äô 

Then we have 17th c. ale ‚Äôn‚Äô cakes, then19th c. kiss ‚Äòn‚Äô tell and, finally, rock‚Äôn‚Äô roll. And then advertisers drop one more apostrophe to make it all more visually pleasing, and now we‚Äôve got our rock n‚Äô roll and cookies n‚Äô cream. 

But we‚Äôre not such a long way from the 13th c. and ‚ÄúOf mete n drynke he had gret nede.‚Äù

I only rarely encounter unknown words on Mondays at the NYT. Today I was stumped by PAROLE and BLAT. Crosses gave me both entries. Having the B of BLAT I thought the answer might be Bray. An ineptly played trumpet does sound like a donkey, doesn't it? Crosses soon did away with that idea though.

I admit to looking up the Japanese name. The surname of the guy I've heard, but his first name was a mystery, and I was a bit lost in that general area. He's the creator of those critically acclaimed animations, isn't he? I saw a trailer of one on Netflix, but I was put off by the frame rate, which resembled a video game played on a way too weak system. I wouldn't be able to watch something so choppy.

A very nice Monday puzzle that managed to be both tricky and easy at the same time with an excellent theme and revealer. 
How do those clever constructors manage that trick???

F sharp is part of the G major scale? I always thought G major consists of G, B, and D.
Someone please explain.
BLAT here is bacon,lettuce, avocado, and tomato.
This was a very fun start to the week. But I really tripped myself up by assuming DRUM SOLO was DRUM ROLL for far too long‚Ä¶

Didn‚Äôt know the director, but VER_SAME must be completed with a Y, right? Nope: ‚ÄúOne square is amiss.‚Äù Maybe it‚Äôs an I? No. I run through the alphabet, convinced there‚Äôs a word there I‚Äôm just not seeing. Nothing. Finally, I look up the director. It WAS a Y!

After much flyspecking: OASES, not OASiS. You got me, Monday puzzle.
Anyone having trouble with Games app this morning?  It won't let me log in.

Personal best to start the week!

As a South African I found it easier because of the fewer because of the fewer proper nouns. I was also excited to see Zulu!

I had guessed BLAR instead of BLAT, which added a minute. 

I‚Äôm leaning piano so the revision of the G Major scale was welcome.
For me this fun puzzle continues my theory that Mondays are getting a bit more difficult which suits most solvers, so why not. A nice aha moment for me when it became clear how the N worked.
Same answer appeared yesterday and today in the crossword (Sunday: 47 down and Monday: 16 across). Not great. Tighter editing needed?
Was I the only one who thought ‚Äúhmmm, they‚Äôve added Rebuses to Mondays now‚Äù until one reached 55-down?  Changed a lot of ‚Äúand‚Äùs to ‚Äún‚Äùs. üòä
This theme ain‚Äôt half b, in fact, it‚Äôs the best thing since sliced bre.  I ore it.
31/41: Cut/Top was my undoing... Over thinking it, again.

New(ish) crossword solver here üëã This was a fun Monday with lots of easy clues mixed in with some complete guesses. Like many others it was OASiS that stumped me. Nice to see a few international references as well such as LOO! 

When I started solving crosswords I saw many of you suggested starting to go through Mondays. Now it‚Äôs like a challenge to myself, when I get a moment, to breeze through (hopefully!) a Monday or two. Slowly but surely I find myself understanding the crosswords üòÑ 

Reading the comments here is always joyful and I appreciate the general positivity of the crossword solving community. With that being said, let me know if there‚Äôs any tips you have for solving! 

Happy Monday!
OASIS would have had me but as a native of the region, ELON was easy. But I didn‚Äôt love VERYSAME.

Nice Monday puzzle. Took me a bit to catch on to the trick, but that was the big turning point and that's always a nice touch. 

I might be away for a bit - moving into a VA facility today. Might be able to get back on line soon, but not sure about that. 

...;.

I liked how uncovering the solo N in two theme answers easified getting the other two.  I liked uncovering AD FREE after trying hard to guess it, and smiled at how clever it is.  

Truly, give me a tough smart riddle, and I‚Äôm happy if I get it and happy if I don‚Äôt (because the sweet effort satisfies my brain‚Äôs workout ethic).

I liked having my five senses pinged through the theme answers alone, and echoed elsewhere in the grid.  I heard a DRUM SOLO, tasted RAVIOLI, took in the aroma of COOKIES N CREAM, even flashed on an image of TRACHEA.

I liked that AT BAT is up ‚Äì Hah!  I liked the four U-enders (FLU, ICU, YOU, ZULU, and wannabe IGLOO).  I liked the AD in IPAD as a theme echo.

Thus, a splendid outing.  Thank you so much for making this, Adam!

Picture caption: It's supposed to be CAREER not CARRIER.
Constructor note: Whomever approved of the name JAZZ SPASTIKS for the group should be fired ASAP. That is EXTREMELY OFFENSIVE because it is antidisability.
The puzzle: O, yes, the puzzle was great. Loved the middle N theme.
VERYSAME?!?!
Smooth 'n' smart, perfect Monday.

I decided that the GM SIGNS ON a new member of the team; this made rather a mess of the BRIDE...
Is AMBER deep yellow or pale brown?
I admit to looking askance at VERY SAME for "aforementioned"... but of course it was fine.
You can make quite a few of the brass instruments go "BLAT!"  ...the learning process for any band instrument is pretty painful at times.  
Monday puzzle now checked off.
(I had a "well, duh" moment with the Spelling Bee.  My excuse is a late night after a taxing day.  Worst moment:  being reminded by DHubby that company was coming around 5 p.m.... at 3:30.  Thank goodness we had planned to go out to dinner.  I'd stay longer, but I need to go check the calendar.)
What kind of bat makes the sound "crack"? And since when do mice "click". Stupid puzzle.

[It goes around every year]
Thanks for reminding me. Gotta get my shot. Wash hands with soap and water. Stop rubbing my eyes.

That clue [Super-uptight] has me thinking about the ego-withering powers of Anal Man, who can find fault with anything, and has nary a wrinkle in his Spandex suit.

The puzzle was fun and almost ad-free, except for that ‚Äúsign up your family‚Äù spot just before I started.

Nice, normal Monday puzzle. 
Some of the game offerings appear to be affected by the AWS outage.

Straightforward Monday, hampered by my electricity dropping out every half hour or so (the electricians are in).
Was thrown by the measure for flour solving to CUP. I forgot that‚Äôs the standard American recipe measure, ergo CUt and tOP SONG looked perfectly good to me.

Unexpected and wonderful revealer! I'll try not to take it personally.

SPORTSBALL ALERT. I'm reminded by recent events of one of the most amazing baseball games I've ever seen:

Vlimir Guerrero the Elder went 4 for 4, with 2 dingers and 9 ribbies for the Angels against the Red Sox. It was not the best game Pedro Martinez ever pitched.

Many of you probably know that Pedro is Vlimir Guerrero Jr.'s godfather. (Although in the game I mentioned, Vl Sr. was Pedro's daddy.)

I don't remember any significance to Bilbo's AGE being 50 in "The Hobbit," but the birthday he celebrated in LOTR is "eleventy-one." Missed opportunity for whimsy.

Wow, it's been a long time since the Atlanta Braves had the best starting pitchers in the league.

I don't see a comment from Mike to reply to, but thought I'd say hello a-nihao.

(If you laugh quietly at this, it will be aloha-ha.)
For those desiring a bit more crunch on your Monday, Rafael Musa has a more challenging puzzle in the New Yorker: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2025/10/20

Has nobody else had the experience of opening the Games app today, being prompted to log in, and then finding that 100% of their stats have vanished?

I‚Äôm not too worried, as I assume this is related to the day‚Äôs AWS outage and will fix itself within a few hours (and in the worst case, I‚Äôll be building a new stats history from scratch‚Ä¶not ideal, but also kind of an interesting thought).

Anyway, I figured I would come here and find most of the discussion centered around the above‚Ä¶and now I‚Äôm thinking it might just be me ü§î

I see from other comments that the games page has been glitchy today. 

For me, when I finished the crossword it played the music, but when I returned to the main games page it showed up as a blue star instead of a gold star, breaking my 2000+ day streak. (This kind og thing has happened before, so I expect that the support team can fix it.)

But I'm surprised that there is no longer an email link to the games support people at the bottom of the crossword or at the bottom of the main games page, like there used to be (unless I'm just not seeing it). What's up with that?

An unusually stupid, even for me, mistake led me to a long hunt for my at least one error. Early on i had N_UR_ at the end of 48A. I figure that it probably ended in E, and I went ahead and "Penned" it in--should have Penciled it. Later when 51D needed five more letters, I automatically filled in SHARP, quite forgetting that G Major was involved. The one black key in E Sharp major is B Flat.

Just read in the NYT that today's Games outage was due to a widespread outage on Amazon Web Services.

Could have been worse - "Many popular services were affected, including WhatsApp, the British government‚Äôs website and tax services, the payment app Venmo, the cryptocurrency platform Coinbase and games at The New York Times. Dozens of other companies and retailers ‚Äî including Amazon, Venmo, Hulu, Snapchat, McDonald‚Äôs, Ring doorbells and the game Fortnite ‚Äî also experienced interruptions."

There is so much we take for granted in this digital world...
This didn't slow me down but isn't the music genre properly ROCK N ROLL, with no AD? Not looking it up but would love to hear what others here have to say about it.
Although we can all agree that RED means stop, here is at least one dissenting voice who would say that AMBER is a shade of orange, not yellow.

I enjoy watching scholars debating over the correctness of the American English language. I enjoy watching scholarly debates over any subject, actually. I think I could seriously party with Sam Lyons all night long. I‚Äôm not so sure about a few other scholars here, but Jaqcui J can join us, while we debate the Rock N‚Äô Roll-ness of Tears for Fears. I do like that song, though.
  I‚Äôve been playing Rock ‚ÄôN Roll for decades now. I am a classically-trained musician from my very early years. I won‚Äôt reveal which stringed instrument I was forced to learn. That‚Äôs a story for another time. Suffice to say, Isaac Stern was my hero, and I display his autographed photo from 1966 in my music studio. He shakes his head a lot at me.
  I had to re-learn everything when I picked up the guitar and started playing Eagles, Hendrix, Santana, Vaughan, Bad Company, Skynyrd, ABB, Clapton, etc. When my guitar teacher, way back when, asked me about my musical journey, I told her that I could read sheet music, tablature and knew music theory quite well. Her reply was ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so sorry to hear that.‚Äù She is a fierce RR/Blues guitarist, a la Lita Ford/Bonnie Raitt. Wow, was she ever right! 
  I learned that Rock ‚ÄôN Roll has rules, but it doesn't. There are mistakes made while playing Rock ‚ÄôN Roll songs, but they‚Äôre not mistakes. Rock ‚ÄôN Roll has structure, but it doesn't.
-- to be continued --
Quick, fun puzzle.  Didn't like VERYSAME as an answer, however, but maybe I've never run into that response/comment.
I liked this quite a bit!

Very late to the party today.

Didn't see the following in my cursory scan of the previous comments, but I can't imagine I'm the only one who entered the Monday-obvious PERIOD for "End of some sentences".

I had just put IPAD in place at 1A, and then went to fill in the four verticals descending from that. ICECAP was fine, but PERIOD had to be quickly retracted.
Hope they fix the stats. Seeing the crossword streak broken is sad

Either BLAT or BRAY fits the unfortunate trumpet sound, but I prefer BLAT. Reminds me of a moment in my college days when I attended a party where too much beer was consumed and the host's [absent] roommate owned a bugle. So we all took turns trying to play it. Definitely BLAT. Pretty close to @Andrzej's pancake hitting the floor. 
  Well, there are far worse things to get into when drunk.

Has anyone ever tried composing a song around the notes that appear in the crosswords in one year, in order?
D-flat yesterday. F sharp today. You‚Äôre welcome.

Aforementioned = VERYSAME?

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

I‚Äôd been told by a fellow inmate prior to my first parole hearing that the way to win the board over was to do a bunch of impressions, so when when I went in I did my best Danny Glover and Eleanor Roosevelt, but it only seemed to make things worse.
Gotta pay attention to those plurals! On a tear, but didn't get the tune at the end... but then again, ILON isn't a university in NC. UGH!
This was a fun one üòä
Please stop non English language words in the mini
Music streaming and podcast services could follow in the footsteps of milkshakes, Joann Jett, and two-course meals to make the world a better place‚Ä¶just sayin‚Äô.

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Easily removed locks]  (3)
[Canniest, for instance]  (7)


WIG
ANAGRAM
@Lewis I missed that second one! I must have gotten the whole word from crosses. It‚Äôs awesome! Thank you for posting it!

@Lewis

I didn't understand Canniest to ANAGRAM when I saw it and I still don't.  What am i missing?  I'm sure it's beautifully clever and even painfully obvious, but not to me.  And I've tried.
@Deadline -- [Canniest, for instance] -- "Canniest" and "instance" are anagrams of each other.  So, the word "canniest" is the anagram for the word "instance".  Does that help?
@Megan I only knew of it from watching ‚ÄòSagwa‚Äô on PBS kids. That, and ‚ÄòXi√®xi√®‚Äô (thank you)
@SP same for me! I don‚Äôt usually get too far before I meet one I don‚Äôt know.

@SP

I was disappointed that manicotti didn‚Äôt fit for the pasta.

@Jacqui J

And I just listened to both Elemental and The Tipping Point this week, both of which I'd never heard before. In fact, I had no idea they were still performing. Loved them in the 80s and love them today!
@Beth in Greenbelt we saw them in 2022 for The Tipping Point tour! Loved it and it was great to see Jamie (their drummer) ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Jacqui J

And "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is one of the randomized six songs you might hear when riding Guardians of the Galaxy: Cosmic Revenge at Epcot. It's a great accompaniment for the ride.

@Jacqui J
Now I'm wondering how that chimp wound up in a Red Sox jersey.

@JayTee every time we drive through Palm Springs on our way to Phoenix, we have to play Everybody Wants to Rule the World since the original video was shot there among the iconic windmills üòÜ. Every. Single. Time.

@Jacqui J
I read that on Wikipedia, too. It doesn't explain why a Red Sox jersey.

@EC

Perhaps the clue should be: ‚Äúracist trope about Inuit people‚Äù or ‚Äúecotourist lodging in the arctic.‚Äù

@Red Carpet

How about simply ‚Äúsnow tent?‚Äù That should do it.
@EC I thought the same thing. Could easily say ‚Äúdomicile made of ice‚Äù or something. Or even ‚Äústructure made from water‚Äù
@EC agreed! Also, Inuit is a plural word already referring to a group of people. A singular Inuit person is an Inuk. ‚ÄúInuits‚Äù is not a real word.

@EC While I agree that the clue is somewhat inaccurate, I‚Äôm not sure the Inuit would take offense as igloo building is still practiced by some Inuit and is seen as an important part of their heritage.
@Cyndie It‚Äôs an incredibly racist trope. But since you persist, do a simple google search.

@EC I did a search and didn‚Äôt find it noted as racist, which doesn‚Äôt mean it isn‚Äôt. I think it‚Äôs worth noting that the Inuit don‚Äôt think it was demeaning to live in Igloos. They kept them very clean and comfortable and view Igloos as culturally important. That being said, I take your point. It is ignorant and stereotypical.
@EC I agree - hints about igloos and teepees (tepee, tipi etc.) could be phrased in ways that don't exoticize Indigenous groups.
@EC Maybe clue it as Adhesive for Apple products

@David S
That took a minute to sink in. Very good!

@Steven M.
Me too. I thought there was something wrong with my brain.

@Francis
LOL. I rise in defence of the reviled dairy product.
Suggestions: 
- Look for blintzes in your grocer's freezer or deli. Slightly sweetened cottage cheese folded into thin crepes and fried in butter.  Yum. Served with jam or (shudder) icing sugar.
- Try broad egg noodles, hot, tossed with CC, cinnamon, sugar, butter. Best with large-curd CC.
- Try the savory version : CC, black pepper, sauteed diced onion and garlic with noodles.
- Blend small-curd CC, yogurt, vanilla extract, lemon juice and zest, melted butter, 1 egg, sugar til smooth. Excellent filling for cheesecake.

See? Even cottage cheese can make your mouth water.

@SBK
My intent was to disparage only that particular brand, which was discontinued a few years ago.  To your list, I'd add a hot baked potato topped with a good cottage cheese.

@Francis And for those of you who are panting to know how my Blue Jays did tonight, they won Game 6. I posted some updates in yesterday's thread: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4b92vr?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share Hope I did this correctly. And Game 7 is on tomorrow night! ‚öæÔ∏èüê¶üçÅüçÅ‚öæÔ∏èüê¶‚öæÔ∏èüçÅüê¶üê¶

@SBK

One game to rule them all.

I like the chances of a team who ties a series at 3-3 at home.

But ya' never know.

@Francis
just let it hang around in cheese cloth for 12 hours and you get fancy paneer.

@SBK
and the canuck, victory fueled, continues to spoil...
@SBK also, fresh local cottage cheese is mikes away from the watery goop people ate in the 80s with half a grapefruit üòÇ
As a lover of all things dairy: this thread is super weird!!!

@Francis

Lost the first two games at home. 
Caught up on the road, but couldn‚Äôt take the series lead in Game 5 in the road. 
Won Game 6 at home. 

Sounds familiar? That‚Äôs the 1986 World Series, Mets vs. Red Sox. When the ball went through Buckner‚Äôs legs to end Game 6 in miraculous fashion. 

The Mets won Game 7.

@SBK

The first two brought back childhood memories. Yum! But now cottage cheese has too much salt, and if there's a low-salt version, it's not available in the miserable supermarkets here, unlike when I lived on the east coast.

@Steve L
üê¶Shhhh! No ill omens please. üê¶üê¶We are neither Mets nor Bosox. üê¶üê¶üê¶Jays manager John Schneider is 'dancing with the one what brung ya' and maintaining a consistent philosophy, to wit:

üê¶üê¶üê¶üê¶Be you.

Go, Jays, go!

@Francis

I'm going to try to do some damage control.  In a moment of confusion I posted that I was wrong that the Blue Jays were at home.

Fortunately, the emus seem to be holding it up.

I don't know how I confused myself, but please ignore any further posts by me on this thread (or ever, unless I stop being so stupid).

@Chili

Sounds like you've been Spirited Away.

@Mike
And syruptitiously split the banana.

@Mike
What's the scoop on "Best Ice Cream in Munster"??
@Mike, ok I'll bite ( lick), but please no Edy's.
I like the way they skirted the whole 'Cookies n Cream' versus 'Cookies n Creme' controversy.

@Mackenzie

Crabbiness is now my subtext.

@Sam Lyons
MERCI. Your post is ROCKNROLL.

@The X-Phile

How is Hungarian any stranger than other languages one does not speak? I mean, even though I've been learning it for almost 40 years, I still find English very strange. In a way, any language I haven't had experience with feels less strange than English - the former is unknown to me so I can't expect to understand what's going on (and that's normal rather than strange), yet the latter still has mysteries after four decades, like BLAT - isn't *that* strange?

@Andrzej

I've been to Budapest twice and my uncle married a woman from there, so I've been around the language a little bit. I don't know what's stranger to me - Hungarian or Polish! Yet I don't speak Dutch or German, but they seem not strange at all. Oh, wait. While typing this I realized that English is considered a Germanic language. Oops!

@SBK

Polish dogs go hau hau ü§∑üèΩ

(Jorge the Lab most definitely woofed though. His father was from Finland. What sounds do Finnish dogs make?)

Blat is an onomatopoeia? Of a sound a trumpet might make? Hmm. If anything, it sounds like a pancake hitting the floor.

@The X-Phile

That strangeness, that eerie cognitive void actually has a name: negative transfer awareness. It‚Äôs where your Indo-European language-speaking brain expects a few anchor points‚Äîsome shared morphemes, sounds, stress rhythms‚Äîand gets none, so it flags the environment as non-intelligible territory. If you have a musical ear, you subconsciously notice when the melody of speech feels alien, lacks familiar prosody and phonological rhythm. If you speak an Indo-European language‚Äîor if you‚Äôve traveled a lot, or just usually choose subtitles vs. voiceover on Netflix‚Äîyour brain is used to picking up recurring morphemes and syntactic cues. Then you get to Budapest or Riga or Helsinki‚Äîand there aren‚Äôt any. Hello, vertigo. 

Years ago, my husband and I rented a car in Istanbul. We hadn‚Äôt been together long enough yet for him to be exposed to anything but this Germanic language of ours, plus his high school Spanish. And then suddenly there was Turkish. I remember his reaction when he realized that there was nothing, zero, nada that he could communicate to the hotel maid. And then at seeing familiar road signs with words that had no resemblance to anything he knew. 

He did learn some Turkish. To this day, he yells ‚ÄúDur! Dur!‚Äù if he thinks I‚Äôm about to do a ‚ÄúCalifornia stop,‚Äù in honor of the word we saw on Turkish stop signs.

@Andrzej
agreed entirely.
the "that language is weird" or "that language is hard" granfalloon is vexing.

@Shekhar G,B,D form the G major chord, the scale goes: G,A,B,C,D,E,F#.

@Shekhar
G, B and D make the Gmaj triad. In Nashville Notation, that would be the 1-3-5.
A study of the Circle of Fifths points out the Order of Sharps and Flats quite nicely.
The key of Gmaj contains one sharp in the tonic scale; the F#.
In earlier Rock N Roll, Country music, and the like, the chord progression is usually 1-4-5. In the key of Gmaj, the G, C and D make up that progression, although not necessarily in that order.
You're now equipped to play with Joan Jett!
